prior_works.title: Crafter: Open-World Survival Game for Reinforcement Learning
prior_works.role: Direct predecessor benchmark and task design
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Craftax-Classic is a ground-up JAX rewrite of Crafter, and the main Craftax benchmark extends Crafter’s mechanics, making Crafter the immediate progenitor of Craftax’s environment structure and objectives.

prior_works.title: The NetHack Learning Environment
prior_works.role: Mechanics and challenge inspiration for open-ended RL
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Craftax borrows NetHack-inspired elements (inventory, survival depth, long-horizon dependencies) to increase exploration and planning difficulty while remaining computationally efficient.

prior_works.title: Procgen Benchmark: Procedurally-Generated Game Environments for Generalization in Reinforcement Learning
prior_works.authors: Ian Cobbe, Chris Hesse, Shane Hilton, John Schulman
prior_works.role: Contrastive benchmark emphasizing speed and diversity
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Procgen exemplifies fast, diverse procedurally generated tasks but limited complexity; Craftax explicitly targets similar throughput while substantially increasing long-horizon complexity and memory demands.

prior_works.title: Minigrid: A Minimalist Gridworld Environment for Reinforcement Learning
prior_works.authors: Maxime Chevalier-Boisvert, Lucas Willems, Suman Pal
prior_works.role: Contrastive simple/fast baseline shaping design goals
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Minigrid represents the fast-but-too-simple end of the spectrum that Craftax aims to surpass in complexity and planning requirements without sacrificing simulation speed.

prior_works.title: Brax: A Differentiable Physics Engine for Large Scale Rigid Body Simulation
prior_works.role: Technical inspiration for accelerator-native, vectorized environments
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Brax demonstrated that JAX+XLA, massive parallelism, and accelerator execution can deliver orders-of-magnitude throughput, a principle Craftax-Classic applies to a discrete open-ended domain.

prior_works.title: JAX: Autograd and XLA
prior_works.authors: James Bradbury, Roy Frostig, Peter Hawkins, Matthew James Johnson, Chris Leary, Dougal Maclaurin, Skye Wanderman-Milne
prior_works.role: Enabling systems technology for speed (JIT, vmap, pmap)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Craftax’s 100x–250x speedups stem from JAX primitives—JIT compilation, vectorization, and GPU execution—enabling end-to-end batched environment stepping and learning on a single accelerator.

prior_works.title: The MineRL Competition on Sample Efficient Reinforcement Learning using Human Priors
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Minecraft/MineRL established crafting/survival as compelling open-ended RL targets but is slow; Craftax seeks similar richness with dramatically lower computational cost.

synthesis_narrative:
Craftax’s core contribution—combining open-ended task complexity with lightning-fast simulation—emerges by reconciling two lines of prior work. On the task-design side, Crafter defines a compact, survival-and-crafting open world that directly seeds Craftax: the authors rewrite Crafter in JAX (Craftax-Classic) and then extend its mechanics. To push difficulty toward deeper exploration, inventory use, and long-horizon dependencies, the design borrows from the NetHack Learning Environment, which has proven the value of roguelike mechanics for probing planning and memory.

On the performance side, Craftax adopts the accelerator-native philosophy popularized by JAX and exemplified by Brax: express the simulator as pure, vectorizable functions, then leverage JIT compilation and batched execution on GPUs/TPUs. This systems approach enables 100x–250x speedups over Python-native simulators and allows billion-step runs on a single GPU. The benchmark’s positioning is sharpened by contrasts with Procgen and Minigrid—fast and diverse but comparatively shallow—versus Minecraft/MineRL—rich and open-ended but slow. Craftax explicitly targets the “fast yet rich” quadrant these benchmarks leave open.

In synthesis, Craftax fuses Crafter’s open-world structure with NetHack-inspired depth, implemented using JAX’s compilation and vectorization paradigm (as in Brax) to deliver unprecedented throughput. The result is a benchmark that preserves the exploration, planning, and memory challenges emblematic of open-ended RL while making large-scale experimentation accessible on modest hardware.
